1.verse: Dear friend who loves God: In my first letter I told you about Jesus’ life and teachings and how he returned to heaven after giving his chosen apostles further instructions from the Holy Spirit.

2.verse: Dear friend who loves God: In my first letter I told you about Jesus’ life and teachings and how he returned to heaven after giving his chosen apostles further instructions from the Holy Spirit.

3.verse: During the forty days after his crucifixion he appeared to the apostles from time to time, actually alive, and proved to them in many ways that it was really he himself they were seeing. And on these occasions he talked to them about the Kingdom of God.

4.verse: In one of these meetings he told them not to leave Jerusalem until the Holy Spirit came upon them in fulfillment of the Father’s promise, a matter he had previously discussed with them.

5.verse: “John baptized you with water,” he reminded them, “but you shall be baptized with the Holy Spirit* in just a few days.”

6.verse: And another time when he appeared to them, they asked him, “Lord, are you going to free Israel from Rome now and restore us as an independent nation?”

7.verse: “The Father sets those dates,” he replied, “and they are not for you to know.

8.verse: But when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, you will receive power to testify about me with great effect, to the people in Jerusalem, throughout Judea, in Samaria, and to the ends of the earth, about my death and resurrection.”

9.verse: It was not long afterwards that he rose into the sky and disappeared into a cloud, leaving them staring after him.

10.verse: As they were straining their eyes for another glimpse, suddenly two white-robed men were standing there among them,

11.verse: and said, “Men of Galilee, why are you standing here staring at the sky? Jesus has gone away to heaven, and some day, just as he went, he will return!”

12.verse: They were at the Mount of Olives when this happened, so now they walked the half mile back to Jerusalem

13.verse: and held a prayer meeting in an upstairs room of the house where they were staying. Here is the list of those who were present at the meeting: Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James (son of Alphaeus), Simon (also called “The Zealot”), Judas (son of James), and the brothers of Jesus.

14.verse: Several women, including Jesus’ mother, were also there.

15.verse: This prayer meeting went on for several days. During this time, on a day when about 120 people were present, Peter stood up and addressed them as follows:

16.verse: “Brothers, it was necessary for the Scriptures to come true concerning Judas, who betrayed Jesus by guiding the mob to him, for this was predicted long ago by the Holy Spirit, speaking through King David.

17.verse: Judas was one of us, chosen to be an apostle just as we were.

18.verse: He bought a field with the money he received for his treachery and falling headlong there, he burst open, spilling out his bowels.

19.verse: The news of his death spread rapidly among all the people of Jerusalem, and they named the place ‘The Field of Blood.’

20.verse: King David’s prediction of this appears in the Book of Psalms, where he says, ‘Let his home become desolate with no one living in it.’ And again, ‘Let his work be given to someone else to do.’

21.verse: “So now we must choose someone else to take Judas’ place and to join us as witnesses of Jesus’ resurrection. Let us select someone who has been with us constantly from our first association with the Lord—from the time he was baptized by John until the day he was taken from us into heaven.”

22.verse: “So now we must choose someone else to take Judas’ place and to join us as witnesses of Jesus’ resurrection. Let us select someone who has been with us constantly from our first association with the Lord—from the time he was baptized by John until the day he was taken from us into heaven.”

23.verse: The assembly nominated two men: Joseph Justus (also called Barsabbas) and Matthias.

24.verse: Then they all prayed for the right man to be chosen. “O Lord,” they said, “you know every heart; show us which of these men you have chosen as an apostle to replace Judas the traitor, who has gone on to his proper place.”

25.verse: Then they all prayed for the right man to be chosen. “O Lord,” they said, “you know every heart; show us which of these men you have chosen as an apostle to replace Judas the traitor, who has gone on to his proper place.”

26.verse: Then they drew straws, and in this manner Matthias was chosen and became an apostle with the other eleven.

1.verse: Seven weeks had gone by since Jesus’ death and resurrection, and the Day of Pentecost had now arrived. As the believers met together that day,

2.verse: suddenly there was a sound like the roaring of a mighty windstorm in the skies above them and it filled the house where they were meeting.

3.verse: Then, what looked like flames or tongues of fire appeared and settled on their heads.

4.verse: And everyone present was filled with the Holy Spirit and began speaking in languages they didn’t know, for the Holy Spirit gave them this ability.

5.verse: Many godly Jews were in Jerusalem that day for the religious celebrations, having arrived from many nations.

6.verse: And when they heard the roaring in the sky above the house, crowds came running to see what it was all about, and were stunned to hear their own languages being spoken by the disciples.

7.verse: “How can this be?” they exclaimed. “For these men are all from Galilee,

8.verse: and yet we hear them speaking all the native languages of the lands where we were born!

9.verse: Here we are—Parthians, Medes, Elamites, men from Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus, Asia Minor,

10.verse: Phrygia, Pamphylia, Egypt, the Cyrene language areas of Libya, visitors from Rome—both Jews and Jewish converts—

11.verse: Cretans, and Arabians. And we all hear these men telling in our own languages about the mighty miracles of God!”

12.verse: They stood there amazed and perplexed. “What can this mean?” they asked each other.

13.verse: But others in the crowd were mocking. “They’re drunk, that’s all!” they said.

14.verse: Then Peter stepped forward with the eleven apostles and shouted to the crowd, “Listen, all of you, visitors and residents of Jerusalem alike!

15.verse: Some of you are saying these men are drunk! It isn’t true! It’s much too early for that! People don’t get drunk by 9:00 A.M.!

16.verse: No! What you see this morning was predicted centuries ago by the prophet Joel—

17.verse: ‘In the last days,’ God said, ‘I will pour out my Holy Spirit upon all mankind, and your sons and daughters shall prophesy, and your young men shall see visions, and your old men dream dreams.

18.verse: Yes, the Holy Spirit shall come upon all my servants, men and women alike, and they shall prophesy.

19.verse: And I will cause strange demonstrations in the heavens and on the earth—blood and fire and clouds of smoke;

20.verse: the sun shall turn black and the moon blood-red before that awesome Day of the Lord arrives.

21.verse: But anyone who asks for mercy from the Lord shall have it and shall be saved.’

22.verse: “O men of Israel, listen! God publicly endorsed Jesus of Nazareth by doing tremendous miracles through him, as you well know.

23.verse: But God, following his prearranged plan, let you use the Roman government to nail him to the cross and murder him.

24.verse: Then God released him from the horrors of death and brought him back to life again, for death could not keep this man within its grip.

25.verse: “King David quoted Jesus as saying: ‘I know the Lord is always with me. He is helping me. God’s mighty power supports me.

26.verse: ‘No wonder my heart is filled with joy and my tongue shouts his praises! For I know all will be well with me in death—

27.verse: ‘You will not leave my soul in hell or let the body of your Holy Son decay.

28.verse: ‘You will give me back my life and give me wonderful joy in your presence.’

29.verse: “Dear brothers, think! David wasn’t referring to himself when he spoke these words I have quoted, for he died and was buried, and his tomb is still here among us.

30.verse: But he was a prophet, and knew God had promised with an unbreakable oath that one of David’s own descendants would be the Messiah and sit on David’s throne.

31.verse: David was looking far into the future and predicting the Messiah’s resurrection, and saying that the Messiah’s soul would not be left in hell and his body would not decay.

32.verse: He was speaking of Jesus, and we all are witnesses that Jesus rose from the dead.

33.verse: “And now he sits on the throne of highest honor in heaven, next to God. And just as promised, the Father gave him the authority to send the Holy Spirit—with the results you are seeing and hearing today.

34.verse: “No, David was not speaking of himself in these words of his I have quoted, for he never ascended into the skies. Moreover, he further stated, ‘God spoke to my Lord, the Messiah, and said to him, Sit here in honor beside me

35.verse: until I bring your enemies into complete subjection.’

36.verse: “Therefore I clearly state to everyone in Israel that God has made this Jesus you crucified to be the Lord, the Messiah!”

37.verse: These words of Peter’s moved them deeply, and they said to him and to the other apostles, “Brothers, what should we do?”

38.verse: And Peter replied, “Each one of you must turn from sin, return to God, and be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins; then you also shall receive this gift, the Holy Spirit.

39.verse: For Christ promised him to each one of you who has been called by the Lord our God, and to your children and even to those in distant lands!”

40.verse: Then Peter preached a long sermon, telling about Jesus and strongly urging all his listeners to save themselves from the evils of their nation.

41.verse: And those who believed Peter were baptized—about three thousand in all!

42.verse: They joined with the other believers in regular attendance at the apostles’ teaching sessions and at the Communion services and prayer meetings.

43.verse: A deep sense of awe was on them all, and the apostles did many miracles.

44.verse: And all the believers met together constantly and shared everything with each other,

45.verse: selling their possessions and dividing with those in need.

46.verse: They worshiped together regularly at the Temple each day, met in small groups in homes for Communion, and shared their meals with great joy and thankfulness,

47.verse: praising God. The whole city was favorable to them, and each day God added to them all who were being saved.

1.verse: Peter and John went to the Temple one afternoon to take part in the three o’clock daily prayer meeting.

2.verse: As they approached the Temple, they saw a man lame from birth carried along the street and laid beside the Temple gate—the one called The Beautiful Gate—as was his custom every day.

3.verse: As Peter and John were passing by, he asked them for some money.

4.verse: They looked at him intently, and then Peter said, “Look here!”

5.verse: The lame man looked at them eagerly, expecting a gift.

6.verse: But Peter said, “We don’t have any money for you! But I’ll give you something else! I command you in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, walk!”

7.verse: Then Peter took the lame man by the hand and pulled him to his feet. And as he did, the man’s feet and ankle bones were healed and strengthened so that he came up with a leap, stood there a moment and began walking! Then, walking, leaping, and praising God, he went into the Temple with them.

8.verse: Then Peter took the lame man by the hand and pulled him to his feet. And as he did, the man’s feet and ankle bones were healed and strengthened so that he came up with a leap, stood there a moment and began walking! Then, walking, leaping, and praising God, he went into the Temple with them.

9.verse: When the people inside saw him walking and heard him praising God,

10.verse: and realized he was the lame beggar they had seen so often at The Beautiful Gate, they were inexpressibly surprised!

11.verse: They all rushed out to Solomon’s Hall, where he was holding tightly to Peter and John! Everyone stood there awed by the wonderful thing that had happened.

12.verse: Peter saw his opportunity and addressed the crowd. “Men of Israel,” he said, “what is so surprising about this? And why look at us as though we by our own power and godliness had made this man walk?

13.verse: For it is the God of Abraham, Isaac, Jacob and of all our ancestors who has brought glory to his servant Jesus by doing this. I refer to the Jesus whom you rejected before Pilate, despite Pilate’s determination to release him.

14.verse: You didn’t want him freed—this holy, righteous one. Instead you demanded the release of a murderer.

15.verse: And you killed the Author of Life; but God brought him back to life again. And John and I are witnesses of this fact, for after you killed him we saw him alive!

16.verse: “Jesus’ name has healed this man—and you know how lame he was before. Faith in Jesus’ name—faith given us from God—has caused this perfect healing.

17.verse: “Dear brothers, I realize that what you did to Jesus was done in ignorance; and the same can be said of your leaders.

18.verse: But God was fulfilling the prophecies that the Messiah must suffer all these things.

19.verse: Now change your mind and attitude to God and turn to him so he can cleanse away your sins and send you wonderful times of refreshment from the presence of the Lord

20.verse: and send Jesus your Messiah back to you again.

21.verse: For he must remain in heaven until the final recovery of all things from sin, as prophesied from ancient times. Moses, for instance, said long ago, ‘The Lord God will raise up a Prophet among you, who will resemble me! Listen carefully to everything he tells you.

22.verse: For he must remain in heaven until the final recovery of all things from sin, as prophesied from ancient times. Moses, for instance, said long ago, ‘The Lord God will raise up a Prophet among you, who will resemble me! Listen carefully to everything he tells you.

23.verse: Anyone who will not listen to him shall be utterly destroyed.’

24.verse: “Samuel and every prophet since have all spoken about what is going on today.

25.verse: You are the children of those prophets; and you are included in God’s promise to your ancestors to bless the entire world through the Jewish race—that is the promise God gave to Abraham.

26.verse: And as soon as God had brought his servant to life again, he sent him first of all to you men of Israel, to bless you by turning you back from your sins.”

1.verse: While they were talking to the people, the chief priests, the captain of the Temple police, and some of the Sadducees came over to them,

2.verse: very disturbed that Peter and John were claiming that Jesus had risen from the dead.

3.verse: They arrested them and since it was already evening, jailed them overnight.

4.verse: But many of the people who heard their message believed it, so that the number of believers now reached a new high of about five thousand men!

5.verse: The next day it happened that the Council of all the Jewish leaders was in session in Jerusalem—

6.verse: Annas the High Priest was there, and Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and others of the High Priest’s relatives.

7.verse: So the two disciples were brought in before them. “By what power, or by whose authority have you done this?” the Council demanded.

8.verse: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, “Honorable leaders and elders of our nation,

9.verse: if you mean the good deed done to the cripple, and how he was healed,

10.verse: let me clearly state to you and to all the people of Israel that it was done in the name and power of Jesus from Nazareth, the Messiah, the man you crucified—but God raised back to life again. It is by his authority that this man stands here healed!

11.verse: For Jesus the Messiah is (the one referred to in the Scriptures when they speak of ) a ‘stone discarded by the builders which became the capstone of the arch.’

12.verse: There is salvation in no one else! Under all heaven there is no other name for men to call upon to save them.”

13.verse: When the Council saw the boldness of Peter and John and could see that they were obviously uneducated non-professionals, they were amazed and realized what being with Jesus had done for them!

14.verse: And the Council could hardly discredit the healing when the man they had healed was standing right there beside them!

15.verse: So they sent them out of the Council chamber and conferred among themselves.

16.verse: “What shall we do with these men?” they asked each other. “We can’t deny that they have done a tremendous miracle, and everybody in Jerusalem knows about it.

17.verse: But perhaps we can stop them from spreading their propaganda. We’ll tell them that if they do it again we’ll really throw the book at them.”

18.verse: So they called them back in, and told them never again to speak about Jesus.

19.verse: But Peter and John replied, “You decide whether God wants us to obey you instead of him!

20.verse: We cannot stop telling about the wonderful things we saw Jesus do and heard him say.”

21.verse: The Council then threatened them further and finally let them go because they didn’t know how to punish them without starting a riot. For everyone was praising God for this wonderful miracle—

22.verse: the healing of a man who had been lame for forty years.

23.verse: As soon as they were freed, Peter and John found the other disciples and told them what the Council had said.

24.verse: Then all the believers united in this prayer: “O Lord, Creator of heaven and earth and of the sea and everything in them—

25.verse: you spoke long ago by the Holy Spirit through our ancestor King David, your servant, saying, ‘Why do the heathen rage against the Lord, and the foolish nations plan their little plots against Almighty God? The kings of the earth unite to fight against him and against the anointed Son of God!’

26.verse: you spoke long ago by the Holy Spirit through our ancestor King David, your servant, saying, ‘Why do the heathen rage against the Lord, and the foolish nations plan their little plots against Almighty God? The kings of the earth unite to fight against him and against the anointed Son of God!’

27.verse: “That is what is happening here in this city today! For Herod the king, and Pontius Pilate the governor, and all the Romans—as well as the people of Israel—are united against Jesus, your anointed Son, your holy servant.

28.verse: They won’t stop at anything that you in your wise power will let them do.

29.verse: And now, O Lord, hear their threats, and grant to your servants great boldness in their preaching,

30.verse: and send your healing power, and may miracles and wonders be done by the name of your holy servant Jesus.”

31.verse: After this prayer, the building where they were meeting shook, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and boldly preached God’s message.

32.verse: All the believers were of one heart and mind, and no one felt that what he owned was his own; everyone was sharing.

33.verse: And the apostles preached powerful sermons about the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and there was warm fellowship among all the believers,

34.verse: and no poverty—for all who owned land or houses sold them and brought the money to the apostles to give to others in need.

35.verse: and no poverty—for all who owned land or houses sold them and brought the money to the apostles to give to others in need.

36.verse: For instance, there was Joseph (the one the apostles nicknamed “Barnabas, the encourager.” He was of the tribe of Levi, from the island of Cyprus).

37.verse: He was one of those who sold a field he owned and brought the money to the apostles for distribution to those in need.

1.verse: But there was a man named Ananias (with his wife Sapphira) who sold some property

2.verse: and brought only part of the money, claiming it was the full price. (His wife had agreed to this deception.)

3.verse: But Peter said, “Ananias, Satan has filled your heart. When you claimed this was the full price, you were lying to the Holy Spirit.

4.verse: The property was yours to sell or not, as you wished. And after selling it, it was yours to decide how much to give. How could you do a thing like this? You weren’t lying to us, but to God.”

5.verse: As soon as Ananias heard these words, he fell to the floor, dead! Everyone was terrified,

6.verse: and the younger men covered him with a sheet and took him out and buried him.

7.verse: About three hours later his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.

8.verse: Peter asked her, “Did you people sell your land for such and such a price?” “Yes,” she replied, “we did.”

9.verse: And Peter said, “How could you and your husband even think of doing a thing like this—conspiring together to test the Spirit of God’s ability to know what is going on? Just outside that door are the young men who buried your husband, and they will carry you out too.”

10.verse: Instantly she fell to the floor, dead, and the young men came in and, seeing that she was dead, carried her out and buried her beside her husband.

11.verse: Terror gripped the entire church and all others who heard what had happened.

12.verse: Meanwhile, the apostles were meeting regularly at the Temple in the area known as Solomon’s Hall, and they did many remarkable miracles among the people.

13.verse: The other believers didn’t dare join them, though, but all had the highest regard for them.

14.verse: And more and more believers were added to the Lord, crowds both of men and women.

15.verse: Sick people were brought out into the streets on beds and mats so that at least Peter’s shadow would fall across some of them as he went by!

16.verse: And crowds came in from the Jerusalem suburbs, bringing their sick folk and those possessed by demons; and every one of them was healed.

17.verse: The High Priest and his relatives and friends among the Sadducees reacted with violent jealousy

18.verse: and arrested the apostles, and put them in the public jail.

19.verse: But an angel of the Lord came at night, opened the gates of the jail and brought them out. Then he told them,

20.verse: “Go over to the Temple and preach about this Life!”

21.verse: They arrived at the Temple about daybreak and immediately began preaching! Later that morning the High Priest and his courtiers arrived at the Temple, and, convening the Jewish Council and the entire Senate, they sent for the apostles to be brought for trial.

22.verse: But when the police arrived at the jail, the men weren’t there, so they returned to the Council and reported,

23.verse: “The jail doors were locked, and the guards were standing outside, but when we opened the gates, no one was there!”

24.verse: When the police captain and the chief priests heard this, they were frantic, wondering what would happen next and where all this would end!

25.verse: Then someone arrived with the news that the men they had jailed were out in the Temple, preaching to the people!

26.verse: The police captain went with his officers and arrested them (without violence, for they were afraid the people would kill them if they roughed up the disciples) and brought them in before the Council.

27.verse: The police captain went with his officers and arrested them (without violence, for they were afraid the people would kill them if they roughed up the disciples) and brought them in before the Council.

28.verse: “Didn’t we tell you never again to preach about this Jesus?” the High Priest demanded. “And instead you have filled all Jerusalem with your teaching and intend to bring the blame for this man’s death on us!”

29.verse: But Peter and the apostles replied, “We must obey God rather than men.

30.verse: The God of our ancestors brought Jesus back to life again after you had killed him by hanging him on a cross.

31.verse: Then, with mighty power, God exalted him to be a Prince and Savior, so that the people of Israel would have an opportunity for repentance, and for their sins to be forgiven.

32.verse: And we are witnesses of these things and so is the Holy Spirit, who is given by God to all who obey him.”

33.verse: At this, the Council was furious and decided to kill them.

34.verse: But one of their members, a Pharisee named Gamaliel (an expert on religious law and very popular with the people), stood up and requested that the apostles be sent outside the Council chamber while he talked.

35.verse: Then he addressed his colleagues as follows: “Men of Israel, take care what you are planning to do to these men!

36.verse: Some time ago there was that fellow Theudas, who pretended to be someone great. About four hundred others joined him, but he was killed, and his followers were harmlessly dispersed.

37.verse: “After him, at the time of the taxation, there was Judas of Galilee. He drew away some people as disciples, but he also died, and his followers scattered.

38.verse: “And so my advice is, leave these men alone. If what they teach and do is merely on their own, it will soon be overthrown.

39.verse: But if it is of God, you will not be able to stop them, lest you find yourselves fighting even against God.”

40.verse: The Council accepted his advice, called in the apostles, had them beaten, and then told them never again to speak in the name of Jesus, and finally let them go.

41.verse: They left the Council chamber rejoicing that God had counted them worthy to suffer dishonor for his name.

42.verse: And every day, in the Temple and in their home Bible classes, they continued to teach and preach that Jesus is the Messiah.

1.verse: But with the believers multiplying rapidly, there were rumblings of discontent. Those who spoke only Greek complained that their widows were being discriminated against, that they were not being given as much food in the daily distribution as the widows who spoke Hebrew.

2.verse: So the Twelve called a meeting of all the believers. “We should spend our time preaching, not administering a feeding program,” they said.

3.verse: “Now look around among yourselves, dear brothers, and select seven men, wise and full of the Holy Spirit, who are well thought of by everyone; and we will put them in charge of this business.

4.verse: Then we can spend our time in prayer, preaching, and teaching.”

5.verse: This sounded reasonable to the whole assembly, and they elected the following: Stephen (a man unusually full of faith and the Holy Spirit), Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, Nicolaus of Antioch (a Gentile convert to the Jewish faith, who had become a Christian).

6.verse: These seven were presented to the apostles, who prayed for them and laid their hands on them in blessing.

7.verse: God’s message was preached in ever-widening circles, and the number of disciples increased vastly in Jerusalem; and many of the Jewish priests were converted too.

8.verse: Stephen, the man so full of faith and the Holy Spirit’s power, did spectacular miracles among the people.

9.verse: But one day some of the men from the Jewish cult of “The Freedmen” started an argument with him, and they were soon joined by Jews from Cyrene, Alexandria in Egypt, and the Turkish provinces of Cilicia, and Asia Minor.

10.verse: But none of them was able to stand against Stephen’s wisdom and spirit.

11.verse: So they brought in some men to lie about him, claiming they had heard Stephen curse Moses, and even God.

12.verse: This accusation roused the crowds to fury against Stephen, and the Jewish leaders arrested him and brought him before the Council.

13.verse: The lying witnesses testified again that Stephen was constantly speaking against the Temple and against the laws of Moses.

14.verse: They declared, “We have heard him say that this fellow Jesus of Nazareth will destroy the Temple and throw out all of Moses’ laws.”

15.verse: At this point everyone in the Council chamber saw Stephen’s face become as radiant as an angel’s!

1.verse: Then the High Priest asked him, “Are these accusations true?”

2.verse: This was Stephen’s lengthy reply: “The glorious God appeared to our ancestor Abraham in Iraq before he moved to Syria,*

3.verse: and told him to leave his native land, to say good-bye to his relatives and to start out for a country that God would direct him to.

4.verse: So he left the land of the Chaldeans and lived in Haran, in Syria, until his father died. Then God brought him here to the land of Israel,

5.verse: but gave him no property of his own, not one little tract of land. “However, God promised that eventually the whole country would belong to him and his descendants—though as yet he had no children!

6.verse: But God also told him that these descendants of his would leave the land and live in a foreign country and there become slaves for 400 years.

7.verse: ‘But I will punish the nation that enslaves them,’ God told him, ‘and afterwards my people will return to this land of Israel and worship me here.’

8.verse: “God also gave Abraham the ceremony of circumcision at that time, as evidence of the covenant between God and the people of Abraham. And so Isaac, Abraham’s son, was circumcised when he was eight days old. Isaac became the father of Jacob, and Jacob was the father of the twelve patriarchs of the Jewish nation.

9.verse: These men were very jealous of Joseph and sold him to be a slave in Egypt. But God was with him,

10.verse: and delivered him out of all of his anguish, and gave him favor before Pharaoh, king of Egypt. God also gave Joseph unusual wisdom so that Pharaoh appointed him governor over all Egypt, as well as putting him in charge of all the affairs of the palace.

11.verse: “But a famine developed in Egypt and Canaan, and there was great misery for our ancestors. When their food was gone,

12.verse: Jacob heard that there was still grain in Egypt, so he sent his sons to buy some.

13.verse: The second time they went, Joseph revealed his identity to his brothers, and they were introduced to Pharaoh.

14.verse: Then Joseph sent for his father Jacob and all his brothers’ families to come to Egypt, seventy-five persons in all.

15.verse: So Jacob came to Egypt, where he died, and all his sons.

16.verse: All of them were taken to Shechem and buried in the tomb Abraham bought from the sons of Hamor, Shechem’s father.

17.verse: “As the time drew near when God would fulfill his promise to Abraham to free his descendants from slavery, the Jewish people greatly multiplied in Egypt; but then a king was crowned who had no respect for Joseph’s memory.

18.verse: “As the time drew near when God would fulfill his promise to Abraham to free his descendants from slavery, the Jewish people greatly multiplied in Egypt; but then a king was crowned who had no respect for Joseph’s memory.

19.verse: This king plotted against our race, forcing parents to abandon their children in the fields.

20.verse: “About that time Moses was born—a child of divine beauty. His parents hid him at home for three months,

21.verse: and when at last they could no longer keep him hidden and had to abandon him, Pharaoh’s daughter found him and adopted him as her own son,

22.verse: and taught him all the wisdom of the Egyptians, and he became a mighty prince and orator.

23.verse: “One day as he was nearing his fortieth birthday, it came into his mind to visit his brothers, the people of Israel.

24.verse: During this visit he saw an Egyptian mistreating a man of Israel. So Moses killed the Egyptian.

25.verse: Moses supposed his brothers would realize that God had sent him to help them, but they didn’t.

26.verse: “The next day he visited them again and saw two men of Israel fighting. He tried to be a peacemaker. ‘Gentlemen,’ he said, ‘you are brothers and shouldn’t be fighting like this! It is wrong!’

27.verse: “But the man in the wrong told Moses to mind his own business. ‘Who made you a ruler and judge over us?’ he asked.

28.verse: ‘Are you going to kill me as you killed that Egyptian yesterday?’

29.verse: “At this, Moses fled the country and lived in the land of Midian, where his two sons were born.

30.verse: “Forty years later, in the desert near Mount Sinai, an Angel appeared to him in a flame of fire in a bush.

31.verse: Moses saw it and wondered what it was, and as he ran to see, the voice of the Lord called out to him,

32.verse: ‘I am the God of your ancestors—of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.’ Moses shook with terror and dared not look.

33.verse: “And the Lord said to him, ‘Take off your shoes, for you are standing on holy ground.

34.verse: I have seen the anguish of my people in Egypt and have heard their cries. I have come down to deliver them. Come, I will send you to Egypt.’

35.verse: And so God sent back the same man his people had previously rejected by demanding, ‘Who made you a ruler and judge over us?’ Moses was sent to be their ruler and savior.

36.verse: And by means of many remarkable miracles he led them out of Egypt and through the Red Sea, and back and forth through the wilderness for forty years.

37.verse: “Moses himself told the people of Israel, ‘God will raise up a Prophet much like me from among your brothers.’

38.verse: How true this proved to be, for in the wilderness, Moses was the go-between—the mediator between the people of Israel and the Angel who gave them the Law of God—the Living Word—on Mount Sinai.

39.verse: “But our fathers rejected Moses and wanted to return to Egypt.

40.verse: They told Aaron, ‘Make idols for us, so that we will have gods to lead us back; for we don’t know what has become of this Moses, who brought us out of Egypt.’

41.verse: So they made a calf idol and sacrificed to it, and rejoiced in this thing they had made.

42.verse: “Then God turned away from them and gave them up, and let them serve the sun, moon, and stars as their gods! In the book of Amos’ prophecies the Lord God asks, ‘Was it to me you were sacrificing during those forty years in the desert, Israel?

43.verse: No, your real interest was in your heathen gods—Sakkuth, and the star god Kaiway, and in all the images you made. So I will send you into captivity far away beyond Babylon.’

44.verse: “Our ancestors carried along with them a portable Temple, or Tabernacle, through the wilderness. In it they kept the stone tablets with the Ten Commandments written on them. This building was constructed in exact accordance with the plan shown to Moses by the Angel.

45.verse: Years later, when Joshua led the battles against the Gentile nations, this Tabernacle was taken with them into their new territory, and used until the time of King David.

46.verse: “God blessed David greatly, and David asked for the privilege of building a permanent Temple for the God of Jacob.

47.verse: But it was Solomon who actually built it.

48.verse: However, God doesn’t live in temples made by human hands. ‘The heaven is my throne,’ says the Lord through his prophets, ‘and earth is my footstool. What kind of home could you build?’ asks the Lord. ‘Would I stay in it?

49.verse: However, God doesn’t live in temples made by human hands. ‘The heaven is my throne,’ says the Lord through his prophets, ‘and earth is my footstool. What kind of home could you build?’ asks the Lord. ‘Would I stay in it?

50.verse: Didn’t I make both heaven and earth?’

51.verse: “You stiff-necked heathen! Must you forever resist the Holy Spirit? But your fathers did, and so do you!

52.verse: Name one prophet your ancestors didn’t persecute! They even killed the ones who predicted the coming of the Righteous One—the Messiah whom you betrayed and murdered.

53.verse: Yes, and you deliberately destroyed God’s laws, though you received them from the hands of angels.”

54.verse: The Jewish leaders were stung to fury by Stephen’s accusation and ground their teeth in rage.

55.verse: But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, gazed steadily upward into heaven and saw the glory of God and Jesus standing at God’s right hand.

56.verse: And he told them, “Look, I see the heavens opened and Jesus the Messiah standing beside God, at his right hand!”

57.verse: Then they mobbed him, putting their hands over their ears, and drowning out his voice with their shouts,

58.verse: and dragged him out of the city to stone him. The official witnesses—the executioners—took off their coats and laid them at the feet of a young man named Paul.

59.verse: And as the murderous stones came hurtling at him, Stephen prayed, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”

60.verse: And he fell to his knees, shouting, “Lord, don’t charge them with this sin!” and with that, he died.

1.verse: Paul was in complete agreement with the killing of Stephen. And a great wave of persecution of the believers began that day, sweeping over the church in Jerusalem, and everyone except the apostles fled into Judea and Samaria.

2.verse: (But some godly Jews came and with great sorrow buried Stephen.)

3.verse: Paul was like a wild man, going everywhere to devastate the believers, even entering private homes and dragging out men and women alike and jailing them.

4.verse: But the believers who had fled Jerusalem went everywhere preaching the Good News about Jesus!

5.verse: Philip, for instance, went to the city of Samaria and told the people there about Christ.

6.verse: Crowds listened intently to what he had to say because of the miracles he did.

7.verse: Many evil spirits were cast out, screaming as they left their victims, and many who were paralyzed or lame were healed,

8.verse: so there was much joy in that city!

9.verse: A man named Simon had formerly been a sorcerer there for many years; he was a very influential, proud man because of the amazing things he could do—in fact, the Samaritan people often spoke of him as the Messiah.

10.verse: A man named Simon had formerly been a sorcerer there for many years; he was a very influential, proud man because of the amazing things he could do—in fact, the Samaritan people often spoke of him as the Messiah.

11.verse: A man named Simon had formerly been a sorcerer there for many years; he was a very influential, proud man because of the amazing things he could do—in fact, the Samaritan people often spoke of him as the Messiah.

12.verse: But now they believed Philip’s message that Jesus was the Messiah, and his words concerning the Kingdom of God; and many men and women were baptized.

13.verse: Then Simon himself believed and was baptized and began following Philip wherever he went, and was amazed by the miracles he did.

14.verse: When the apostles back in Jerusalem heard that the people of Samaria had accepted God’s message, they sent down Peter and John.

15.verse: As soon as they arrived, they began praying for these new Christians to receive the Holy Spirit,

16.verse: for as yet he had not come upon any of them. For they had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

17.verse: Then Peter and John laid their hands upon these believers, and they received the Holy Spirit.

18.verse: When Simon saw this—that the Holy Spirit was given when the apostles placed their hands upon people’s heads—he offered money to buy this power.

19.verse: “Let me have this power too,” he exclaimed, “so that when I lay my hands on people, they will receive the Holy Spirit!”

20.verse: But Peter replied, “Your money perish with you for thinking God’s gift can be bought!

21.verse: You can have no part in this, for your heart is not right before God.

22.verse: Turn from this great wickedness and pray. Perhaps God will yet forgive your evil thoughts—

23.verse: for I can see that there is jealousy and sin in your heart.”

24.verse: “Pray for me,” Simon exclaimed, “that these terrible things won’t happen to me.”

25.verse: After testifying and preaching in Samaria, Peter and John returned to Jerusalem, stopping at several Samaritan villages along the way to preach the Good News to them too.

26.verse: But as for Philip, an angel of the Lord said to him, “Go over to the road that runs from Jerusalem through the Gaza Desert, arriving around noon.”

27.verse: So he did, and who should be coming down the road but the Treasurer of Ethiopia, a eunuch of great authority under Candace the queen. He had gone to Jerusalem to worship

28.verse: and was now returning in his chariot, reading aloud from the book of the prophet Isaiah.

29.verse: The Holy Spirit said to Philip, “Go over and walk along beside the chariot.”

30.verse: Philip ran over and heard what he was reading and asked, “Do you understand it?”

31.verse: “Of course not!” the man replied. “How can I when there is no one to instruct me?” And he begged Philip to come up into the chariot and sit with him.

32.verse: The passage of Scripture he had been reading from was this: “He was led as a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb is silent before the shearers, so he opened not his mouth;

33.verse: in his humiliation, justice was denied him; and who can express the wickedness of the people of his generation? For his life is taken from the earth.”

34.verse: The eunuch asked Philip, “Was Isaiah talking about himself or someone else?”

35.verse: So Philip began with this same Scripture and then used many others to tell him about Jesus.

36.verse: As they rode along, they came to a small body of water, and the eunuch said, “Look! Water! Why can’t I be baptized?”

37.verse: “You can,” Philip answered, “if you believe with all your heart.” And the eunuch replied, “I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.”

38.verse: He stopped the chariot, and they went down into the water and Philip baptized him.

39.verse: And when they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, and the eunuch never saw him again, but went on his way rejoicing.

40.verse: Meanwhile, Philip found himself at Azotus! He preached the Good News there and in every city along the way, as he traveled to Caesarea.

1.verse: But Paul, threatening with every breath and eager to destroy every Christian, went to the High Priest in Jerusalem.

2.verse: He requested a letter addressed to synagogues in Damascus, requiring their cooperation in the persecution of any believers he found there, both men and women, so that he could bring them in chains to Jerusalem.

3.verse: As he was nearing Damascus on this mission, suddenly a brilliant light from heaven spotted down upon him!

4.verse: He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, “Paul! Paul! Why are you persecuting me?”

5.verse: “Who is speaking, sir?” Paul asked. And the voice replied, “I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting!

6.verse: Now get up and go into the city and await my further instructions.”

7.verse: The men with Paul stood speechless with surprise, for they heard the sound of someone’s voice but saw no one!

8.verse: As Paul picked himself up off the ground, he found that he was blind. He had to be led into Damascus and was there three days, blind, going without food and water all that time.

9.verse: As Paul picked himself up off the ground, he found that he was blind. He had to be led into Damascus and was there three days, blind, going without food and water all that time.

10.verse: Now there was in Damascus a believer named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a vision, calling, “Ananias!” “Yes, Lord!” he replied.

11.verse: And the Lord said, “Go over to Straight Street and find the house of a man named Judas and ask there for Paul of Tarsus. He is praying to me right now, for

12.verse: I have shown him a vision of a man named Ananias coming in and laying his hands on him so that he can see again!”

13.verse: “But Lord,” exclaimed Ananias, “I have heard about the terrible things this man has done to the believers in Jerusalem!

14.verse: And we hear that he has arrest warrants with him from the chief priests, authorizing him to arrest every believer in Damascus!”

15.verse: But the Lord said, “Go and do what I say. For Paul is my chosen instrument to take my message to the nations and before kings, as well as to the people of Israel.

16.verse: And I will show him how much he must suffer for me.”

17.verse: So Ananias went over and found Paul and laid his hands on him and said, “Brother Paul, the Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road, has sent me so that you may be filled with the Holy Spirit and get your sight back.”

18.verse: Instantly (it was as though scales fell from his eyes) Paul could see and was immediately baptized.

19.verse: Then he ate and was strengthened. He stayed with the believers in Damascus for a few days

20.verse: and went at once to the synagogue to tell everyone there the Good News about Jesus—that he is indeed the Son of God!

21.verse: All who heard him were amazed. “Isn’t this the same man who persecuted Jesus’ followers so bitterly in Jerusalem?” they asked. “And we understand that he came here to arrest them all and take them in chains to the chief priests.”

22.verse: Paul became more and more fervent in his preaching, and the Damascus Jews couldn’t withstand his proofs that Jesus was indeed the Christ.

23.verse: After a while the Jewish leaders determined to kill him.

24.verse: But Paul was told about their plans, that they were watching the gates of the city day and night prepared to murder him.

25.verse: So during the night some of his converts let him down in a basket through an opening in the city wall!

26.verse: Upon arrival in Jerusalem he tried to meet with the believers, but they were all afraid of him. They thought he was faking!

27.verse: Then Barnabas brought him to the apostles and told them how Paul had seen the Lord on the way to Damascus, what the Lord had said to him, and all about his powerful preaching in the name of Jesus.

28.verse: Then they accepted him, and after that he was constantly with the believers

29.verse: and preached boldly in the name of the Lord. But then some Greek-speaking Jews with whom he had argued plotted to murder him.

30.verse: However, when the other believers heard about his danger, they took him to Caesarea and then sent him to his home in Tarsus.

31.verse: Meanwhile, the church had peace throughout Judea, Galilee and Samaria, and grew in strength and numbers. The believers learned how to walk in the fear of the Lord and in the comfort of the Holy Spirit.

32.verse: Peter traveled from place to place to visit them, and in his travels came to the believers in the town of Lydda.

33.verse: There he met a man named Aeneas, paralyzed and bedridden for eight years.

34.verse: Peter said to him, “Aeneas! Jesus Christ has healed you! Get up and make your bed.” And he was healed instantly.

35.verse: Then the whole population of Lydda and Sharon turned to the Lord when they saw Aeneas walking around.

36.verse: In the city of Joppa there was a woman named Dorcas (“Gazelle”), a believer who was always doing kind things for others, especially for the poor.

37.verse: About this time she became ill and died. Her friends prepared her for burial and laid her in an upstairs room.

38.verse: But when they learned that Peter was nearby at Lydda, they sent two men to beg him to return with them to Joppa.

39.verse: This he did; as soon as he arrived, they took him upstairs where Dorcas lay. The room was filled with weeping widows who were showing one another the coats and other garments Dorcas had made for them.

40.verse: But Peter asked them all to leave the room; then he knelt and prayed. Turning to the body he said, “Get up, Dorcas,” and she opened her eyes! And when she saw Peter, she sat up!

41.verse: He gave her his hand and helped her up and called in the believers and widows, presenting her to them.

42.verse: The news raced through the town, and many believed in the Lord.

43.verse: And Peter stayed a long time in Joppa, living with Simon, the tanner.

1.verse: In Caesarea there lived a Roman army officer, Cornelius, a captain of an Italian regiment.

2.verse: He was a godly man, deeply reverent, as was his entire household. He gave generously to charity and was a man of prayer.

3.verse: While wide awake one afternoon he had a vision—it was about three o’clock—and in this vision he saw an angel of God coming toward him. “Cornelius!” the angel said.

4.verse: Cornelius stared at him in terror. “What do you want, sir?” he asked the angel. And the angel replied, “Your prayers and charities have not gone unnoticed by God!

5.verse: Now send some men to Joppa to find a man named Simon Peter, who is staying with Simon, the tanner, down by the shore, and ask him to come and visit you.”

6.verse: Now send some men to Joppa to find a man named Simon Peter, who is staying with Simon, the tanner, down by the shore, and ask him to come and visit you.”

7.verse: As soon as the angel was gone, Cornelius called two of his household servants and a godly soldier, one of his personal bodyguard,

8.verse: and told them what had happened and sent them off to Joppa.

9.verse: The next day as they were nearing the city, Peter went up on the flat roof of his house to pray. It was noon and he was hungry, but while lunch was being prepared, he fell into a trance.

10.verse: The next day as they were nearing the city, Peter went up on the flat roof of his house to pray. It was noon and he was hungry, but while lunch was being prepared, he fell into a trance.

11.verse: He saw the sky open and a great canvas sheet, suspended by its four corners, settle to the ground.

12.verse: In the sheet were all sorts of animals, snakes, and birds forbidden to the Jews for food.

13.verse: Then a voice said to him, “Go kill and eat any of them you wish.”

14.verse: “Never, Lord,” Peter declared, “I have never in all my life eaten such creatures, for they are forbidden by our Jewish laws.”

15.verse: The voice spoke again, “Don’t contradict God! If he says something is kosher, then it is.”

16.verse: The same vision was repeated three times. Then the sheet was pulled up again to heaven.

17.verse: Peter was very perplexed. What could the vision mean? What was he supposed to do? Just then the men sent by Cornelius had found the house and were standing outside at the gate,

18.verse: inquiring whether this was the place where Simon Peter lived!

19.verse: Meanwhile, as Peter was puzzling over the vision, the Holy Spirit said to him, “Three men have come to see you.

20.verse: Go down and meet them and go with them. All is well, I have sent them.”

21.verse: So Peter went down. “I’m the man you’re looking for,” he said. “Now what is it you want?”

22.verse: Then they told him about Cornelius the Roman officer, a good and godly man, well thought of by the Jews, and how an angel had instructed him to send for Peter to come and tell him what God wanted him to do.

23.verse: So Peter invited them in and lodged them overnight. The next day he went with them, accompanied by some other believers from Joppa.

24.verse: They arrived in Caesarea the following day, and Cornelius was waiting for him and had called together his relatives and close friends to meet Peter.

25.verse: As Peter entered his home, Cornelius fell to the floor before him in worship.

26.verse: But Peter said, “Stand up! I’m not a god!”

27.verse: So he got up, and they talked together for a while and then went in where the others were assembled.

28.verse: Peter told them, “You know it is against the Jewish laws for me to come into a Gentile home like this. But God has shown me in a vision that I should never think of anyone as inferior.

29.verse: So I came as soon as I was sent for. Now tell me what you want.”

30.verse: Cornelius replied, “Four days ago I was praying as usual at this time of the afternoon, when suddenly a man was standing before me clothed in a radiant robe!

31.verse: He told me, ‘Cornelius, your prayers are heard and your charities have been noticed by God!

32.verse: Now send some men to Joppa and summon Simon Peter, who is staying in the home of Simon, a tanner, down by the shore.’

33.verse: So I sent for you at once, and you have done well to come so soon. Now here we are, waiting before the Lord, anxious to hear what he has told you to tell us!”

34.verse: Then Peter replied, “I see very clearly that the Jews are not God’s only favorites!

35.verse: In every nation he has those who worship him and do good deeds and are acceptable to him.

36.verse: I’m sure you have heard about the Good News for the people of Israel—that there is peace with God through Jesus, the Messiah, who is Lord of all creation. This message has spread all through Judea, beginning with John the Baptist in Galilee.

37.verse: I’m sure you have heard about the Good News for the people of Israel—that there is peace with God through Jesus, the Messiah, who is Lord of all creation. This message has spread all through Judea, beginning with John the Baptist in Galilee.

38.verse: And you no doubt know that Jesus of Nazareth was anointed by God with the Holy Spirit and with power, and he went around doing good and healing all who were possessed by demons, for God was with him.

39.verse: “And we apostles are witnesses of all he did throughout Israel and in Jerusalem, where he was murdered on a cross.

40.verse: But God brought him back to life again three days later and showed him to certain witnesses God had selected beforehand—not to the general public, but to us who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead.

41.verse: But God brought him back to life again three days later and showed him to certain witnesses God had selected beforehand—not to the general public, but to us who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead.

42.verse: And he sent us to preach the Good News everywhere and to testify that Jesus is ordained of God to be the Judge of all—living and dead.

43.verse: And all the prophets have written about him, saying that everyone who believes in him will have their sins forgiven through his name.”

44.verse: Even as Peter was saying these things, the Holy Spirit fell upon all those listening!

45.verse: The Jews who came with Peter were amazed that the gift of the Holy Spirit would be given to Gentiles too!

46.verse: But there could be no doubt about it, for they heard them speaking in tongues and praising God. Peter asked, “Can anyone object to my baptizing them, now that they have received the Holy Spirit just as we did?”

47.verse: But there could be no doubt about it, for they heard them speaking in tongues and praising God. Peter asked, “Can anyone object to my baptizing them, now that they have received the Holy Spirit just as we did?”

48.verse: So he did, baptizing them in the name of Jesus, the Messiah. Afterwards Cornelius begged him to stay with them for several days.

1.verse: Soon the news reached the apostles and other brothers in Judea that Gentiles also were being converted!

2.verse: But when Peter arrived back in Jerusalem, the Jewish believers argued with him.

3.verse: “You fellowshiped with Gentiles and even ate with them,” they accused.

4.verse: Then Peter told them the whole story.

5.verse: “One day in Joppa,” he said, “while I was praying, I saw a vision—a huge sheet, let down by its four corners from the sky.

6.verse: Inside the sheet were all sorts of animals, reptiles, and birds which we are not to eat.

7.verse: And I heard a voice say, ‘Kill and eat whatever you wish.’

8.verse: “‘Never, Lord,’ I replied. ‘For I have never yet eaten anything forbidden by our Jewish laws!’

9.verse: “But the voice came again, ‘Don’t say it isn’t right when God declares it is!’

10.verse: “This happened three times before the sheet and all it contained disappeared into heaven.

11.verse: Just then three men who had come to take me with them to Caesarea arrived at the house where I was staying!

12.verse: The Holy Spirit told me to go with them and not to worry about their being Gentiles! These six brothers here accompanied me, and we soon arrived at the home of the man who had sent the messengers.

13.verse: He told us how an angel had appeared to him and told him to send messengers to Joppa to find Simon Peter!

14.verse: ‘He will tell you how you and all your household can be saved!’ the angel had told him.

15.verse: “Well, I began telling them the Good News, but just as I was getting started with my sermon, the Holy Spirit fell on them, just as he fell on us at the beginning!

16.verse: Then I thought of the Lord’s words when he said, ‘Yes, John baptized with water, but you shall be baptized with* the Holy Spirit.’

17.verse: And since it was God who gave these Gentiles the same gift he gave us when we believed on the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I to argue?”

18.verse: When the others heard this, all their objections were answered and they began praising God! “Yes,” they said, “God has given to the Gentiles, too, the privilege of turning to him and receiving eternal life!”

19.verse: Meanwhile, the believers who fled from Jerusalem during the persecution after Stephen’s death traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, scattering the Good News, but only to Jews.

20.verse: However, some of the believers who went to Antioch from Cyprus and Cyrene also gave their message about the Lord Jesus to some Greeks.

21.verse: And the Lord honored this effort so that large numbers of these Gentiles became believers.

22.verse: When the church at Jerusalem heard what had happened, they sent Barnabas to Antioch to help the new converts.

23.verse: When he arrived and saw the wonderful things God was doing, he was filled with excitement and joy, and encouraged the believers to stay close to the Lord, whatever the cost.

24.verse: Barnabas was a kindly person, full of the Holy Spirit and strong in faith. As a result, large numbers of people were added to the Lord.

25.verse: Then Barnabas went on to Tarsus to hunt for Paul.

26.verse: When he found him, he brought him back to Antioch; and both of them stayed there for a full year teaching the many new converts. (It was there at Antioch that the believers were first called “Christians.”)

27.verse: During this time some prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch,

28.verse: and one of them, named Agabus, stood up in one of the meetings to predict by the Spirit that a great famine was coming upon the land of Israel. (This was fulfilled during the reign of Claudius.)

29.verse: So the believers decided to send relief to the Christians in Judea, each giving as much as he could.

30.verse: This they did, consigning their gifts to Barnabas and Paul to take to the elders of the church in Jerusalem.

1.verse: About that time King Herod moved against some of the believers

2.verse: and killed the apostle James (John’s brother).

3.verse: When Herod saw how much this pleased the Jewish leaders, he arrested Peter during the Passover celebration

4.verse: and imprisoned him, placing him under the guard of sixteen soldiers. Herod’s intention was to deliver Peter to the Jews for execution after the Passover.

5.verse: But earnest prayer was going up to God from the church for his safety all the time he was in prison.

6.verse: The night before he was to be executed, he was asleep, double-chained between two soldiers with others standing guard before the prison gate,

7.verse: when suddenly there was a light in the cell and an angel of the Lord stood beside Peter! The angel slapped him on the side to awaken him and said, “Quick! Get up!” And the chains fell off his wrists!

8.verse: Then the angel told him, “Get dressed and put on your shoes.” And he did. “Now put on your coat and follow me!” the angel ordered.

9.verse: So Peter left the cell, following the angel. But all the time he thought it was a dream or vision and didn’t believe it was really happening.

10.verse: They passed the first and second cell blocks and came to the iron gate to the street, and this opened to them of its own accord! So they passed through and walked along together for a block, and then the angel left him.

11.verse: Peter finally realized what had happened! “It’s really true!” he said to himself. “The Lord has sent his angel and saved me from Herod and from what the Jews were hoping to do to me!”

12.verse: After a little thought he went to the home of Mary, mother of John Mark, where many were gathered for a prayer meeting.

13.verse: He knocked at the door in the gate, and a girl named Rhoda came to open it.

14.verse: When she recognized Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed that she ran back inside to tell everyone that Peter was standing outside in the street.

15.verse: They didn’t believe her. “You’re out of your mind,” they said. When she insisted they decided, “It must be his angel. They must have killed him.”

16.verse: Meanwhile Peter continued knocking. When they finally went out and opened the door, their surprise knew no bounds.

17.verse: He motioned for them to quiet down and told them what had happened and how the Lord had brought him out of jail. “Tell James and the others what happened,” he said—and left for safer quarters.

18.verse: At dawn, the jail was in great commotion. What had happened to Peter?

19.verse: When Herod sent for him and found that he wasn’t there, he had the sixteen guards arrested, court-martialed and sentenced to death. Afterwards he left to live in Caesarea for a while.

20.verse: While he was in Caesarea, a delegation from Tyre and Sidon arrived to see him. He was highly displeased with the people of those two cities, but the delegates made friends with Blastus, the royal secretary, and asked for peace, for their cities were economically dependent upon trade with Herod’s country.

21.verse: An appointment with Herod was granted, and when the day arrived he put on his royal robes, sat on his throne, and made a speech to them.

22.verse: At its conclusion the people gave him a great ovation, shouting, “It is the voice of a god and not of a man!”

23.verse: Instantly, an angel of the Lord struck Herod with a sickness so that he was filled with maggots and died—because he accepted the people’s worship instead of giving the glory to God.

24.verse: God’s Good News was spreading rapidly and there were many new believers.

25.verse: Barnabas and Paul now visited Jerusalem and as soon as they had finished their business, returned to Antioch, taking John Mark with them.

1.verse: Among the prophets and teachers of the church at Antioch were Barnabas and Symeon (also called “The Black Man”), Lucius (from Cyrene), Manaen (the foster-brother of King Herod), and Paul.

2.verse: One day as these men were worshiping and fasting the Holy Spirit said, “Dedicate Barnabas and Paul for a special job I have for them.”

3.verse: So after more fasting and prayer, the men laid their hands on them—and sent them on their way.

4.verse: Directed by the Holy Spirit they went to Seleucia and then sailed for Cyprus.

5.verse: There, in the town of Salamis, they went to the Jewish synagogue and preached. (John Mark went with them as their assistant.)

6.verse: Afterwards they preached from town to town across the entire island until finally they reached Paphos where they met a Jewish sorcerer, a fake prophet named Bar-Jesus. He had attached himself to the governor, Sergius Paulus, a man of considerable insight and understanding. The governor invited Barnabas and Paul to visit him, for he wanted to hear their message from God.

7.verse: Afterwards they preached from town to town across the entire island until finally they reached Paphos where they met a Jewish sorcerer, a fake prophet named Bar-Jesus. He had attached himself to the governor, Sergius Paulus, a man of considerable insight and understanding. The governor invited Barnabas and Paul to visit him, for he wanted to hear their message from God.

8.verse: But the sorcerer, Elymas (his name in Greek), interfered and urged the governor to pay no attention to what Paul and Barnabas said, trying to keep him from trusting the Lord.

9.verse: Then Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, glared angrily at the sorcerer and said,

10.verse: “You son of the devil, full of every sort of trickery and villainy, enemy of all that is good, will you never end your opposition to the Lord?

11.verse: And now God has laid his hand of punishment upon you, and you will be stricken awhile with blindness.” Instantly mist and darkness fell upon him, and he began wandering around begging for someone to take his hand and lead him.

12.verse: When the governor saw what happened, he believed and was astonished at the power of God’s message.

13.verse: Now Paul and those with him left Paphos by ship for Turkey, landing at the port town of Perga. There John Mark deserted them* and returned to Jerusalem.

14.verse: But Barnabas and Paul went on to Antioch, a city in the province of Pisidia. On the Sabbath they went into the synagogue for the services.

15.verse: After the usual readings from the Books of Moses and from the Prophets, those in charge of the service sent them this message: “Brothers, if you have any word of instruction for us come and give it!”

16.verse: So Paul stood, waved a greeting to them and began. “Men of Israel,” he said, “and all others here who reverence God, let me begin my remarks with a bit of history.*

17.verse: “The God of this nation Israel chose our ancestors and honored them in Egypt by gloriously leading them out of their slavery.

18.verse: And he nursed them through forty years of wandering around in the wilderness.

19.verse: Then he destroyed seven nations in Canaan and gave Israel their land as an inheritance. Judges ruled for about four hundred and fifty years and were followed by Samuel the prophet.

20.verse: Then he destroyed seven nations in Canaan and gave Israel their land as an inheritance. Judges ruled for about four hundred and fifty years and were followed by Samuel the prophet.

21.verse: “Then the people begged for a king, and God gave them Saul (son of Kish), a man of the tribe of Benjamin, who reigned for forty years.

22.verse: But God removed him and replaced him with David as king, a man about whom God said, ‘David (son of Jesse) is a man after my own heart, for he will obey me.’

23.verse: And it is one of King David’s descendants, Jesus, who is God’s promised Savior of Israel!

24.verse: “But before he came, John the Baptist preached the need for everyone in Israel to turn from sin to God.

25.verse: As John was finishing his work he asked, ‘Do you think I am the Messiah? No! But he is coming soon—and in comparison with him, I am utterly worthless.’

26.verse: “Brothers—you sons of Abraham, and also all of you Gentiles here who reverence God—this salvation is for all of us!

27.verse: The Jews in Jerusalem and their leaders fulfilled prophecy by killing Jesus; for they didn’t recognize him or realize that he is the one the prophets had written about, though they heard the prophets’ words read every Sabbath.

28.verse: They found no just cause to execute him, but asked Pilate to have him killed anyway.

29.verse: When they had fulfilled all the prophecies concerning his death, he was taken from the cross and placed in a tomb.

30.verse: “But God brought him back to life again!

31.verse: And he was seen many times during the next few days by the men who had accompanied him to Jerusalem from Galilee—these men have constantly testified to this in public witness.

32.verse: “And now Barnabas and I are here to bring you this Good News—that God’s promise to our ancestors has come true in our own time, in that God brought Jesus back to life again. This is what the second Psalm is talking about when it says concerning Jesus, ‘Today I have honored you as my Son.’

33.verse: “And now Barnabas and I are here to bring you this Good News—that God’s promise to our ancestors has come true in our own time, in that God brought Jesus back to life again. This is what the second Psalm is talking about when it says concerning Jesus, ‘Today I have honored you as my Son.’

34.verse: “For God had promised to bring him back to life again, no more to die. This is stated in the Scripture that says, ‘I will do for you the wonderful thing I promised David.’

35.verse: In another Psalm he explained more fully, saying, ‘God will not let his Holy One decay.’

36.verse: This was not a reference to David, for after David had served his generation according to the will of God, he died and was buried, and his body decayed.

37.verse: No, it was a reference to another—someone God brought back to life, whose body was not touched at all by the ravages of death.*

38.verse: “Brothers! Listen! In this man Jesus there is forgiveness for your sins!

39.verse: Everyone who trusts in him is freed from all guilt and declared righteous—something the Jewish law could never do.

40.verse: Oh, be careful! Don’t let the prophets’ words apply to you. For they said,

41.verse: ‘Look and perish, you despisers of the truth, for I am doing something in your day—something that you won’t believe when you hear it announced.’”

42.verse: As the people left the synagogue that day, they asked Paul to return and speak to them again the next week.

43.verse: And many Jews and godly Gentiles who worshiped at the synagogue followed Paul and Barnabas down the street as the two men urged them to accept the mercies God was offering.

44.verse: The following week almost the entire city turned out to hear them preach the Word of God.

45.verse: But when the Jewish leaders saw the crowds, they were jealous, and cursed* and argued against whatever Paul said.

46.verse: Then Paul and Barnabas spoke out boldly and declared, “It was necessary that this Good News from God should be given first to you Jews. But since you have rejected it and shown yourselves unworthy of eternal life—well, we will offer it to Gentiles.

47.verse: For this is as the Lord commanded when he said, ‘I have made you a light to the Gentiles, to lead them from the farthest corners of the earth to my salvation.’”

48.verse: When the Gentiles heard this, they were very glad and rejoiced in Paul’s message; and as many as wanted eternal life, believed.

49.verse: So God’s message spread all through that region.

50.verse: Then the Jewish leaders stirred up both the godly women and the civic leaders of the city and incited a mob against Paul and Barnabas, and ran them out of town.

51.verse: But they shook off the dust of their feet against the town and went on to the city of Iconium.

52.verse: And their converts were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.

1.verse: At Iconium, Paul and Barnabas went together to the synagogue and preached with such power that many—both Jews and Gentiles—believed.

2.verse: But the Jews who spurned God’s message stirred up distrust among the Gentiles against Paul and Barnabas, saying all sorts of evil things about them.

3.verse: Nevertheless, they stayed there a long time, preaching boldly, and the Lord proved their message was from him by giving them power to do great miracles.

4.verse: But the people of the city were divided in their opinion about them. Some agreed with the Jewish leaders, and some backed the apostles.

5.verse: When Paul and Barnabas learned of a plot to incite a mob of Gentiles, Jews, and Jewish leaders to attack and stone them, they fled for their lives, going to the cities of Lycaonia, Lystra, Derbe, and the surrounding area,

6.verse: When Paul and Barnabas learned of a plot to incite a mob of Gentiles, Jews, and Jewish leaders to attack and stone them, they fled for their lives, going to the cities of Lycaonia, Lystra, Derbe, and the surrounding area,

7.verse: and preaching the Good News there.

8.verse: While they were at Lystra, they came upon a man with crippled feet who had been that way from birth, so he had never walked.

9.verse: He was listening as Paul preached, and Paul noticed him and realized he had faith to be healed.

10.verse: So Paul called to him, “Stand up!” and the man leaped to his feet and started walking!

11.verse: When the listening crowd saw what Paul had done, they shouted (in their local dialect, of course), “These men are gods in human bodies!”

12.verse: They decided that Barnabas was the Greek god Jupiter, and that Paul, because he was the chief speaker, was Mercury!

13.verse: The local priest of the Temple of Jupiter, located on the outskirts of the city, brought them cartloads of flowers and prepared to sacrifice oxen to them at the city gates before the crowds.

14.verse: But when Barnabas and Paul saw what was happening, they ripped at their clothing in dismay and ran out among the people, shouting,

15.verse: “Men! What are you doing? We are merely human beings like yourselves! We have come to bring you the Good News that you are invited to turn from the worship of these foolish things and to pray instead to the living God, who made heaven and earth and sea and everything in them.

16.verse: In bygone days he permitted the nations to go their own ways,

17.verse: but he never left himself without a witness; there were always his reminders—the kind things he did such as sending you rain and good crops and giving you food and gladness.”

18.verse: But even so, Paul and Barnabas could scarcely restrain the people from sacrificing to them!

19.verse: Yet only a few days later, some Jews arrived from Antioch and Iconium and turned the crowds into a murderous mob that stoned Paul and dragged him out of the city, apparently dead.

20.verse: But as the believers stood around him, he got up and went back into the city! The next day he left with Barnabas for Derbe.

21.verse: After preaching the Good News there and making many disciples, they returned again to Lystra, Iconium and Antioch,

22.verse: where they helped the believers to grow in love for God and each other. They encouraged them to continue in the faith in spite of all the persecution, reminding them that they must enter into the Kingdom of God through many tribulations.

23.verse: Paul and Barnabas also appointed elders in every church and prayed for them with fasting, turning them over to the care of the Lord in whom they trusted.

24.verse: Then they traveled back through Pisidia to Pamphylia,

25.verse: preached again in Perga, and went on to Attalia.

26.verse: Finally they returned by ship to Antioch, where their journey had begun and where they had been committed to God for the work now completed.

27.verse: Upon arrival they called together the believers and reported on their trip, telling how God had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles too.

28.verse: And they stayed there with the believers at Antioch for a long while.

1.verse: While Paul and Barnabas were at Antioch, some men from Judea arrived and began to teach the believers that unless they adhered to the ancient Jewish custom of circumcision, they could not be saved.

2.verse: Paul and Barnabas argued and discussed this with them at length, and finally the believers sent them to Jerusalem, accompanied by some local men, to talk to the apostles and elders there about this question.

3.verse: After the entire congregation had escorted them out of the city, the delegates went on to Jerusalem, stopping along the way in the cities of Phoenicia and Samaria to visit the believers, telling them—much to everyone’s joy—that the Gentiles, too, were being converted.

4.verse: Arriving in Jerusalem, they met with the church leaders—all the apostles and elders were present—and Paul and Barnabas reported on what God had been doing through their ministry.

5.verse: But then some of the men who had been Pharisees before their conversion stood to their feet and declared that all Gentile converts must be circumcised and required to follow all the Jewish customs and ceremonies.

6.verse: So the apostles and church elders set a further meeting to decide this question.

7.verse: At the meeting, after long discussion, Peter stood and addressed them as follows: “Brothers, you all know that God chose me from among you long ago to preach the Good News to the Gentiles so that they also could believe.

8.verse: God, who knows men’s hearts, confirmed the fact that he accepts Gentiles by giving them the Holy Spirit, just as he gave him to us.

9.verse: He made no distinction between them and us, for he cleansed their lives through faith, just as he did ours.

10.verse: And now are you going to correct God by burdening the Gentiles with a yoke that neither we nor our fathers were able to bear?

11.verse: Don’t you believe that all are saved the same way, by the free gift of the Lord Jesus?”

12.verse: There was no further discussion, and everyone now listened as Barnabas and Paul told about the miracles God had done through them among the Gentiles.

13.verse: When they had finished, James took the floor. “Brothers,” he said, “listen to me.

14.verse: Peter has told you about the time God first visited the Gentiles to take from them a people to bring honor to his name.

15.verse: And this fact of Gentile conversion agrees with what the prophets predicted. For instance, listen to this passage from the prophet Amos:

16.verse: ‘Afterwards’ (says the Lord), ‘I will return and renew the broken contract with David,*

17.verse: so that Gentiles, too, will find the Lord—all those marked with my name.’

18.verse: That is what the Lord says, who reveals his plans made from the beginning.

19.verse: “And so my judgment is that we should not insist that the Gentiles who turn to God must obey our Jewish laws,

20.verse: except that we should write to them to refrain from eating meat sacrificed to idols, from all fornication, and also from eating unbled meat of strangled animals.

21.verse: For these things have been preached against in Jewish synagogues in every city on every Sabbath for many generations.”

22.verse: Then the apostles and elders and the whole congregation voted to send delegates to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas, to report on this decision. The men chosen were two of the church leaders—Judas (also called Barsabbas) and Silas.

23.verse: This is the letter they took along with them: “From: The apostles, elders and brothers at Jerusalem. “To: The Gentile brothers in Antioch, Syria and Cilicia. Greetings!

24.verse: “We understand that some believers from here have upset you and questioned your salvation, but they had no such instructions from us.

25.verse: So it seemed wise to us, having unanimously agreed on our decision, to send to you these two official representatives, along with our beloved Barnabas and Paul.

26.verse: These men—Judas and Silas, who have risked their lives for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ—will confirm orally what we have decided concerning your question.

27.verse: “For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay no greater burden of Jewish laws on you than to abstain from eating food offered to idols and from unbled meat of strangled animals, and, of course, from fornication. If you do this, it is enough. Farewell.”

28.verse: “For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay no greater burden of Jewish laws on you than to abstain from eating food offered to idols and from unbled meat of strangled animals, and, of course, from fornication. If you do this, it is enough. Farewell.”

29.verse: “For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay no greater burden of Jewish laws on you than to abstain from eating food offered to idols and from unbled meat of strangled animals, and, of course, from fornication. If you do this, it is enough. Farewell.”
